body: If `const fetch = require('node-fetch');` works, investigate your transpiler setup first.

Honestly, as the loader specification is still very much up in the air (and all npm modules should still be distributing CommonJS style exports into the foreseeable future) I highly suggest just using `require` and avoiding the headache. You also get the bonus of being able to destructure on the same line you require.

For now, you should be able to use

```ts
import fetch = require('node-fetch');
```

as documented at https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/modules.html#export--and-import--require

Does Typescript definition file handle this type of things? If so might need to contact its author to support node-fetch 2.0

(From my phone)

> 在 2017年7月10日，11:06，Timothy Gu <notifications@github.com> 写道：
> 
> Argh, another module system. Reopening...
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
>

> Does Typescript definition file handle this type of things?

I don't think so. Just specifying `fetch.default = fetch` should be enough to fix this issue, though I'd prefer handling it in the compiler plugins ([Babel](https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/blob/master/build/babel-plugin.js), [Rollup](https://github.com/bitinn/node-fetch/blob/master/build/rollup-plugin.js)).

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.title: Support TypeScript import in browser

repository.name: node-fetch
repository.description: A light-weight module that brings the Fetch API to Node.js

issue.body:
Related to #307 and #332.

TypeScript is compiling
```
import fetch from 'node-fetch';
fetch(url, options)
```
into
```
const node_fetch_1 = require("node-fetch");
node_fetch_1.default(url, options)
```

This works great in Node.js thanks to #332 but doesn't work in the browser (I'm using Webpack, so it correctly uses the `browser.js` script specified in `package.json`).
